Headline: A Pea By Many Names
Text: Cowpea, crowder pea, black-eyed-pea, gubgub, chowlee, لوبيا‎ (lūbiyā), alubia carilla, feijão-frade, mkunde, catjang: the plant has thousands of common names all around the world. Today its botanical name is Vigna unguiculata--let's take a look at how we got there.

Headline: Dioscorides (40-90 CE)
Text: Dioscorides in his work De Materia Medica (On Medical Material) called the plant δολιχός (dólikhos), derived from the Ancient Greek word for a long racecourse. This could be because the vines are long, the pods are long, or both. This illustration from a later copy of De Materia Medica shows Dioscorides seated on the left. On the right is Heuresis, the personification of Discovery.

Headline: Pliny the Elder (24-79 CE)
Text: Another common term of the era was Greek φᾰ́σηλος (phásēlos), which became the Latin Phaseolus. Book 18 of Pliny's Natural History praises the plant's vigor and many uses, calling it the "only grain that even when grazed down by cattle fills out again when the moon is waxing."

Headline: Juliana Anicia Codex (c. 512 CE)
Text: Dioscorides was the standard reference text for European physicians and pharmacists for 1500 years. The oldest surviving copy of De Materia Medica is known today as the Juliana Anicia Codex, commissioned as a gift for a Byzantine imperial princess by that name. The codex was written in Greek and the images were later labeled in Arabic and Hebrew by an unknown hand.
Media Caption: Vigna unguiculata from Codex Aniciae Julianae c.512 CE

Headline: Carolus Clusius (1526-1609)
Text: Carolus Clusius’s influential Rariorum Plantarum Historia (History of Rare Plants), refers to cowpea as Phaseolus peregrinus IIII. Peregrinus comes from the Latin peregre, meaning foreign or distant (literally per- ‘through’ + ager ‘field'). This suggestion of foreignness cuts the cowpea off from its long history in Europe.

Headline: John Gerard (1545-1612)
Text: In a 1636 edition of English botanist John Gerard’s Herball, or Generall historie of plants, he used Clusius's name Phaseolus peregrinus IIII, describing it as the “Indian Kidney bean with small white fruit.” Although the plant originated in Africa and had been present in Europe for centuries, specimens received from the Americas could arrive in various conditions. This left it up to each botanist's judgment to determine which plants were familiar and which were novel.

Botanical gardens developed across Europe in order to grow and study plants from both near and far. A 1683 record of Edinburgh’s Physical Garden, for example, contains a Phaseolus described as a “small white Kidney-bean with a black spot in the middle.”

Headline: Carl Linnaeus (1707-1778)
Text: In his Species Plantarum of 1753, Linnaeus gave the name Dolichos unguiculatus to a specimen from Barbados. Three years later in Centuria Plantarum, he named another specimen Dolichos sinensis; the Latin word "sinensis" means "from China" and suggests that the latter specimen was collected in East or Southeast Asia. Early scientists' collecting networks greatly impacted their understanding of a plant's origin.

Headline: Nikolaus von Jacquin (1727-1817)
Text: Jacquin and his illustrator Franz von Scheidl made this color plate and labeled it with Linnaeus's term Dolichos unguiculatus

Headline: Wilhelm Walpers (1816-1853)
Text: Walpers spent his brief career re-evaluating Linnaeus's taxonomy in a series of commentary published as Repertorium Botanices Systematicae (Systematic Botanical Repository). He reclassified the species as Vigna unguiculata, with a nod to Jacquin's work as his source. Today, the botanical name is followed by "L. Walp." to credit both Linnaeus and Walpers
